I've played both of them rather extensively and League is a laggy at times 
and needs consistent server or game work at times, but all in all its 
pretty decent. Dota 2 rarely any server lag and they don't have to do as 
much maintaining of the game cause they don't come out with something new 
every month or so.

I will say in gameplay the main difference seems to be this. In league its 
way more about teamwork cause unless you are a pro and can get fed real 
quick early game and become extremely good late you can't carry a team so 
if your team sucks 9/10 you are gonna lose. So your team needs to be at 
least semi-competent to win in league cause it won't matter too too much if 
one person screws up cause of character design and like I said they have to 
be pro to carry if the rest of their team didn't do well.. Okay now the 
same can be said for Dota, but the affects of feeding someone are a lot 
more present cause if one person screws up bad the fed player can literally 
fuck up an entire enemy team pretty easy. So assuming they don't dick 
around and every other lane didn't intentionally feed you probably are 
gonna win. Kinda sad that the game that requires more teamwork has the 
shittiest player base.

That and the only difference I can see is League does update and change 
things a lot. They always are coming up with New Characters and adjusting 
different things to where its noticeable. I know Dota updates to, but often 
times when I play after an update I can't really tell they changed anything 
because it wasn't significant enough to make that much of a difference.

Anyway that's my personal opinion as for any other MOBA's haven't played 
them so I'm not even gonna touch on that. As for what my opinion is on 
which is better IDK. Depends on what you want or are willing to do. If you 
wanna just get good, fuck people up without having to worry too too much 
about what your team does , and play a game that doesn't flip everything 
upside down with updates go for DOTA 2, but if your willing to play a game 
with assholes and that gets significant changes and always provides a newer 
experience then League is for you. My personal opinion and both games are 
really good just like I said depends on what you want.

The amount of people bitching at League being #1 over Dota2 is hilarious. 
League is #1 simply because it's the most popular PC game of all-time. Or 
at least somewhere way up there. Even more so than Dota2. It's the 
most-viewed game on Twitch and has one of the largest, if not the largest, 
fanbases of any multiplayer game. Of course it's going to be heralded as 
the best of it's genre with all that going for it. The beauty of both 
League and Dota is that there is no true #1 because of how certain people 
adapt to MOBAs. You have those who excel at them and are really good right 
away. They mainly play Dota. Then you have the ones who play for fun or who 
adapt at a slower rate. They usually play League and sometimes will play 
Dota too. It's not about skill level, so Dota players stop with that 
argument. I know really good Dota players who prefer League because of its 
popularity and how much fun they have playing it. It's about which game 
appeals to you more. It just so happens that League is more appealing to 
majority of MOBA players than Dota is.﻿

+Franco Massai So you're saying that there's no such thing as a "counter"

Because my experience says different. And those that have access and 
practised all the characters, are going to have an advantage in more games. 
Because they'll have first hand knowledge of how that character works. And 
if you don't have access to these characters... you aren't going to know 
how to play against them as well as someone who does have access to that 
character.

so to say there is no advantage to having all the characters at your 
disposal is bullshit... Because you do get "counters" and you do learn what 
characters are capable of by using them.

Note: I play All Random in DOTA2 almost exclusively when I solo queue... 
this gives me knowledge and experience with all the heroes. This means that 
when I play with friends, I can pick a Hero that has synergy with their 
selections or I can pick a hero which is strong against the enemy team, and 
perform well in that role.

A very long time. If they keep releasing champions, by the time you get 
every champion up until today there will be like 8 (or more) new ones and 
you would have spent like 2 years playing. However, you can pay to get them 
(wich doesn't give you any advantage) so... Yeah.

Tip: Having all characters isn't important in any moba, try to learn every 
role in the game with 3 or 4 champions per role and you are set.

with some important tweaks. It didn't gather too much more of a following 
until Steve Feak released his take on DotA with DotA Allstars. DotA 
Allstars became immensely popular and Feak ran it for three years until he 
joined Riot Games in 2005/6 and began development on a new MOBA called 
League of Legends. He handed the reins over to IceFrog who continued to 
develop DotA Allstars until 2009 when he began work on DotA 2. You probably 
know the rest.

Anyway, the point is that both games took heavy inspiration from earlier 
MOBAs and are good games in their own right. Neither of the two developers 
are evil or cheap, they're just different.

I used to play LoL a lot, especially with friends, however, the friends I 
played with got INCREDIBLY competitive and would rage really easily, not 
want to hear any sort of constructive criticism/advice, etc. We stopped 
talking to one guy because of people getting upset in League. I did try 
DoTA 2 a few times, but the mechanics of that game were a bit of a turn off 
after being so used to League. I did try Smite as well, but couldn't get 
into its third person view.

Now, my moba of choice is Infinite Crisis, which is in open beta right now. 
For those interested, it's a moba based on the DC Comics story arc of the 
same name, and features DC characters of multiple universes, such as a 
Batman in a nightmarish universe where he's been turned into a vampire, or 
a Green Lantern in a universe damaged by global nuclear warfare. The item 
system is simple, credits are easier to share, not nearly as much of a 
focus on runes/masteries as LoL.

I don't find the argument "X game sucks because it's a cheap rip-off of Y 
game" to hold any ground whatsoever, except maybe in the case of 300 
Heroes, because:
1. Every single one of these mobas (again, with the exception of 300 
Heroes) does something different enough to be its own game. Awesomenauts 
definitely deserves some bonus points for making their moba a platformer 
and not the top-down view so many of us are used to. Smite does something 
different too, but I just couldn't get into it, as the camera style hinders 
my all-around vision.
2. DoTA 2 was not the first moba, nor was League, so saying that one was a 
direct copy of another is like saying one FPS game is a direct copy of 
another FPS game. They're in the same genre, so similarities are going to 
exist. ﻿

LoL has a higher playbase and a easy to learn, hard to master gameplay in 
general. All champions are unique in their own way. LoL is slightly less 
balanced, often having champions notorious for being OP. You can gain 
currency to boost your stats over all games, making a veteran player have 
quite a bit of an advantage over newer players. You can also use this 
currency to unlock more champions, which you could potentially use to 
counter others while preventing them from being able to counter you. 
Cosmetics in LoL come in a form of skins or models you can use to replace 
your usual look, and often cost anywhere from 1-15 USD. You can not trade 
or return skins or champions bought.

DotA has a higher skillcap and punishes mistakes more dramatically, making 
it difficult for new players to start. All heroes are drastically different 
from another, and not knowing what each one can do can be fatal. DotA is 
however, a more balanced game. Players with more game time or cosmetics 
hold no advantage over new players. All heroes are unlocked by default, and 
sets(in dota, each set or "skin" can be mixed and matched with other parts 
of other sets) are usually only 2.49 USD or less. Additionally, you can 
sell(or give to your friends) unwanted items for actual money you can 
proceed to spend on the Steam Store, or buy specific items in the Steam 
Marketplace.

fight the character is in; if the character has a fatal flaw, such as high

+Tyler Wardle
Likely the reason they named League over DOTA 2 is that it is much easier. 
Since DOTA 2 has denying creep kills, a courier to bring items to you, and 
the Strength/Intelligence/Agility set up, it is much harder to play, since 
there are many more things you need to be aware of--not to mention that a 
new DOTA 2 player will almost never get any creeps versus someone who 
constantly denies them.
On the other hand, League is much more open to new players since there's no 
denying cs except pushing to tower, builds are pretty much whatever works 
with your skills in particular, and (though I wish it were in league), you 
don't get distracted by a courier and shop while out in the field, which 
can easily kill a person not paying attention. Also a not as malleable meta 
makes it easier for people to find a place the like in laning (though you 
try to break the meta and people get so stupidly angry).
Overall, I think they chose to name League over DOTA 2 for the fact that 
it's more accessible to newer players.

+Cedrock Except all league of legends tournaments use twitch. But not all 
DOTA tournaments use Twitch, some use Daily motion some use MLG's website 
and ALL tournament matches can be watched on the ingame client with the 
ability to choose your own camera, as well as select a hero and use 
"perspective" so you can see every single click they perform if you are a 
fanboy of that particular player or just want to learn how to play that 
hero better.

There's also give aways with every tournament, just being in the game gives 
a chance of getting a drop when something happens. There are triggers for 
first bloods, multi kills, courier kills, rapier purchases, suicides and 
some more I can't remember right now. So a lot of people choose to watch on 
the ingame client. because everytime one of these things trigger, 3 people 
get gifts.

Not to mention, that since LCS is pretty much only at the weekends, the 
professionals that are in LCS have much more free time to stream during the 
week, so their fans have a schedule to follow them. While professional dota 
happens 7 days a week, so the players don't have as much structure to have 
a schedule for streaming... But if that's not enough to convince you... 

http://www.esportsearnings.com/players

lists 20 dota players in the top 100 esports earners, and only 10 league 
players. So it's obvious where the money is. And that brings with it more 
sponsors and so on.

Additionally, the sheer volume of community created hats for dota is 
insane. Which gives artists and players a chance to make money with dota. I 
myself have had items drop that are worth serious money. And I can sell 
these in the market place. While on the other side of the coin... it's all 
Riot making money from skins, with the occasional charity one. Valve sell 
items voted into the game through the workshop made by fans of the game and 
artists. And those people get credited with their creation and a share of 
the sales.

And even more reasons﻿

1) Personal preference
2) Personal opinion
3) Fair point
4) LoL has 6v6 mode but personally I liked Demigods modes best.  (That and 
ability draft wouldn't work in a game where you have more ability types 
than Mana and nothing else)
5) Made by Guinsoo, the maker of LoL, adapted to run on source instead of 
on WC3 engine.
6) LoL updates weekly to bi-weekly and releases characters faster so again 
I'd say preference
7) LoL has a black guy?  I'm just messing, I still like Enigma and Chaos 
Knight but to be fair, most Dota characters are just blatant copy/pastes of 
WC3 heroes.  LoL keeps it original. (skins aside)
8) I'd say they're about equal, LoL is more about learning your character 
while Dota is more about learning the map. (secret shop and tree consuming 
paths anyone?)
9) Needless mechanic if you ask me, LoL can indirectly deny (pushing 
minions, stacking lane, body blocking) which makes it much harder than

+Stephen Aguilon For a more simpler explanation on why LoL is unbalanced, 
there are a set of game designers that their sole role is to balance and 
tweak champions, skills, and neutral monsters. When they go through 
multiple patches, mechanics of the champions, which is everything from 
basic damage, attack animation length, and skills, it takes a long time to 
balance a champion. The champions themselves in the game are well balanced, 
but when you add modifications to the balanced champions before the game 
starts, they become unbalanced. An ADC with extra 21 base damage at the 
beginning will have a huge advantage over the other ADC (who is newer) with 
no runes. that extra damage can completely dominate a lane by itself, even 
without skill.

If this list was objectively made though Dota 2 would currently take the 
number 1 spot. For now that is. There are new MOBAs coming out all the 
time. Who knows if some of those is better than Dota. The reason Dota 2 
should easily take the number 1 spot is as follows: More depth to the game, 
payment model is superior, graphics style is superior, the spell effects 
are easier to see and recognize therefore reducing the amount of senseless 
chaos in the game. This isn't even debatable. If you do say otherwise.. 
Open your eyes. Now subjectively speaking.. LoL and Dota both are equal of 
course, because people have different kind of preferences. Dota has a 
bigger learning curve, LoL is more forgiving and has less hidden mechanics 
to master. But if somebody has the balls to say that objectively speaking 
LoL is better then he / she is living in a dreamland.

+TrueWOPR You got it all wrong, budso. It all started in Starcraft with 
Aeon of Strife, which had a very small community but as Blizzard released 
WC3 Eul decided to take the idea and implement it into WC3, he gave the 
heroes levels and items too, as WC3 allowed. There were lots of different 
DotA versions flying around, each with their own heroes when one man took 
the best of the best and created DotA Allstars, which he gave to Guinsoo, 
who did very little, only a few balance changes. Guinsoo soon passed the 
flag over to Icefrog, when the game really started to pick up and become 
big. A lot of people consider Icefrog the "real" owner of DotA, as the game 
became the most successful under his name, both pre-DotA2 and after. 
Icefrog proceeded to make balance changes, shifting the meta around very 
cleverly all by himself while still keeping the game balanced and fun. 
Icefrog worked a few years on DotA BEFORE he was CONTACTED by Valve to make 
the game for them. He still releases the same updates to DotA as he does to 
DotA 2.

Still two different companies developing different games. The two games are 
distinct enough to not be a ripoff of the other.

+bladexj **sigh** You don't know anything about the history of LoL/Dota do 
you...  Once upon a time a guy made a map for WC3 called "Defense of the 
Ancients" it soon gathered a following but had many requests for changes 
and adjustments because balance was the last thing on the creators mind, he 
then passed the map to Guinsoo who made it what it was today.  After making 
it the best he could he had the bright idea to turn it into a standalone 
version so people who didn't have WC3 could play it as well, thus League of 
Legends was born, having this new powerhouse of a game in his arms he had 
to pass DotA down to someone, and thus IceFrog got his grubby hands on it 
and quickly proceeded to make very minor balance changes, do nothing else, 
claim he is the heart and soul of the game, then sell it to Valve in which 
he slaps a 2 on the end despite that nothing between the two has changed 
aside from graphics engine.

And thus is the story of League of Legends and Defense of the Ancients 
HD...  I mean 2.
